newsitem.title: UK: Teamsters back UPS Italian strikers over layoffs.
newsitem.headline: Teamsters back UPS Italian strikers over layoffs.

text.p: The U.S. Teamsters union has written to United Parcel Services Italy protesting against UPS plans to cut 150 jobs in Italy.

Teamsters president Ron Carey said the union is registering its "strongest possible protest over the treatment of UPS workers in Italy" and urged UPS Italy "to reconsider its harsh stance against the workers just demands for full-time and secure jobs free from harsh working conditions."

"As a major global corporation, UPS must abide by international standards of acceptable behaviour for multi-national companies," he said in a letter obtained by Reuters. "UPS's treatment of its Italian work force violates these standards."
Carey said Teamsters represents nearly 200,000 UPS workers in the U.S.

Under Italian labour laws the job cuts will start to take effect in 45 days from March 6. A national eight-hour strike of the 900 UPS Italy staff is scheduled for March 28 with further action planned for April.
Delegates from the company's Spanish unions are meeting in Milan today, and union sources said Spanish staff plan action in support of that by their Italian counterparts.
Air express industry sources said that on February 11-12 , the Teamsters meet with other unions from around the world who also bargain with UPS to form the World UPS Trade Union Council.
The unions said they would provide mutual support and exchange information about their dealings with UPS at a national level.

UPS said it had not been invited to participate or contribute to the meeting and: "As such we are unable to comment. However UPS does welcome open communication with its employees and actively communicates with its staff representatives."
Other industry sources noted that the current four-year UPS-Teamster contract in the U.S. is up for renewal in July.

Carey said he understood the Italian unions intended to continue their action until a fair agreement is negotiated. "It is not only right that you do this, it is also important for business reasons. If UPS gets a global reputation as a company which has labor problems overseas and experiences frequent disruptions, its large customer base in the United States may decide to take their business elsewhere." --Reuters Air Cargo Newsroom Tel+44 171 542-7706 Fax+5017
